bibl.title: Letter from William S. Thayer to Mabel H. Lazear, June 29, 1904

div1.p: Thayer believes that Lazear should receive credit for being the first to advocate the mosquito theory to the Yellow Fever Commission.

div1.head: Letter from William S. Thayer to Mabel H. Lazear, June 29, 1904
div1.opener:
DR. W. S. THAYER,
405 CATHEDRAL STREET.
CONSULTATION HOURS,
2.30-4.30 P. M.
BALTIMORE,
June 29, 1904.
Dear Mrs. Lazear:-
div1.p:
The brass plate, as Dr. Paton has I think written you, is done and is
really fine. It will be unveiled probably at the time of the exercises of the opening
of the new medical rooms at the hospital. I saw Dr. Osler day before yesterday and he
quite agreed with me that we ought to have some special dedicatory exercises in connection
with the plate. I shall want myself to say a few special words. I feel quite convinced
that the world at large and more than that, those who really ought to know the facts,
are unaware of the full part which Lazear played in the work of the Yellow Fever Commission
I know well enough that there is nothing more undignified and mistaken than strife with
regard to questions of priority but unless I am very much mistaken there are some simple
facts with regard to Lazear's work that I could state on this occasion in such a way
as to offend no one and to do only good. While every one who know Reed was devoted to
him and every one is enthusiastic about the plans for the Reed Memorial I feel that
people ought to know-if it be true and I believe it is- that the first suggestion of
the mosquito work - the original ideas and plans, came from Lazear. No one would have
been quicker to acknowledge it than Reed had he been alive to-day. I remember very well
a conversation that I had in my office in which you hinted at certain ideas that Lazear
had worked out, and it occurred to me that you might care to tell me a few facts or to
let me have a few extracts from his letters which might enable me to say something to
the point. I should of course feel myself bound to say nothing which I had not pre-
viously submitted to you. I do not know whether you ever saw a letter of Dr. Agramonte
to the Journal of the American Medical Association which was published on the 13th of
June of last year. It was in a controversy with regard to rather a stupid point I think -
the amount of credit that should be given to Dr. Finley. In this letter he says: “I
DR. W. S. THAYER,
405 CATHEDRAL STREET.
CONSULTATION HOURS,
2.30-4.30 P. M.
BALTIMORE.
was present when the question of following out Dr. Finley's mosquito theory was brought
up by the Army Yellow Fever Board ****At that time neither Drs. Reed, Carroll nor myself
believed in said theory, the only one of us inclined to consider it favorably being
my friend and classmate, Dr. Jesse W. Lazear. That the work in the lines of Finley's
theory was undertaken as a matter of course from the fact that a thorough investigation
into the aetiology of yellow fever was expected of our Board, and not because as a body
the Board thought any too well of it. That of us all Dr. Lazear was the only one at
the time prepared to initiate the work in this direction, he being thoroughly familiar
with the anatomy and biology of the culex and conversant with the technique required;
he had bred numerous varieties in his laboratory at Camp Columbia and had been sending
specimens to Dr. Howard the entomologist, Department of Agriculture, Washington, for aid
in identifying different species. That Dr. Lazear was the member of the Board, Dr. Reed
being absent in Washington, who produced the first two cases by the bites of mosquitoes
in the presence of Dr. Carroll, who, being an unbeliever, allowed him to apply one mosquito
on August 27 and an American soldier who was bitten by the same mosquito, and three
others August 31, 1900. That Dr. Lazear not content with this and not in ignorance, for
he had suggested to me what the origin of Carroll's and the soldier's infection was, de-
liberately allowed himself to be bitten by the mosquito, while in one of the wards of
the Yellow Fever Hospital (Las Anamas) September 13, at a time when Carroll and the sol-
dier were convalescing from their attacks. I am convinced that this mosquito produced
the infection which caused his death September 25, 1900.

Major Reed was summoned from Washington and the investigation was then undertaken
exclusively on the mosquito theory.
These are the facts which I deem necessary to make known for the present”.

DR. W. S. THAYER,
405 CATHEDRL STREET,

I fancy that this is true, and that you have always been aware of it. To bring such:
facts out more forcibly and in such a way that it in no way detracts from the honour
due to Dr. Reed, would it seems to me be easy on such an occasion as the unveiling of
the plate. Should you not like to have me do this?

It seems a long time since I have heard from you. I sincerely hope that you and
the children are well. With cordial good wishes, I am,
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, W.S. Thayer. Mrs. Jesse W. Lazear,
2012 N. Broadway,
San Francisco, California.
